_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Dow Chemical Company

Union Carbide Marine Terminal

EPA ID# 1000 0012 9933



Risk Management Plan Five-Year Update 

Executive Summary



Description of the Facility and Purpose of Submittal 



Union Carbide Texas City Operations is a manufacturing facility that annually produces more than 

five (5) billion pounds of chemicals and plastics including hydrocarbons, specialty polymers, 

solvents, intermediates, monomers and industrial products.  Union Carbide Marine Terminal is 

located three (3) miles from Union Carbide Texas City Operations and assists in the 

transportation and distribution of chemicals and products from the main plant.  In accordance with 

U.S. EPA regulation 40 CFR 68, the U.S. EPA has identified quantities for 140 toxic or flammable 

substances that require a facility to comply with the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule when 

unit inventories exceed threshold quantities.  The RMP rule requires a facility to report the unit 

inventory for each RMP substance that exceeds threshold quantities, along with an EPA 

approved chemical release prevention program.  In addition, 40 CFR 68 requires all RMP 

covered facilities to update its Risk Management Plan (RMPlan) every five (5) years or six (6) 

months after an RMP reportable incident. Union Carbide Marine Terminal initially submitted its 

RMPlan in June 1999.  In compliance with 40 CFR 68, Union Carbide Marine Terminal is 

submitting the five (5) year update to its initial RMPlan submittal.



Union Carbide Marine Terminal currently holds the following RMP-regulated substances above 

threshold quantities:



Propylene - CAS No. 115-07-1

Vinyl Acetate Monomer - CAS No. 108-05-4



Key Offsite Consequence Analysis 



40 CFR 68 requires all facilities, subject to the rule, to conduct an offsite consequence analysis to 

provide information about any potential consequences of an accidental chemical release to the 

public and state and federal environmental agencies.  Offsite cons

equence analyses are 

essential in identifying potential hazards of accidental release. The offsite consequence analysis 

(OCA) comprises 2 elements, a worst case scenario and an alternative release scenario.



Worst Case Scenarios



Offsite consequence analyses for the worst-case scenarios (WCS) were conducted using the 

Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines.  The 

RMP sets forth specific criteria that must be incorporated in modeling the worst-case scenarios.  

The EPA defines a WCS as one that results in the greatest distance from the point of release to a 

specified endpoint.  As defined by the rule, the endpoint for a toxic substance is a specified 

concentration while for flammables it is a specified overpressure from a vapor cloud explosion 

(VCE).

The scenarios for Union Carbide Texas City Operations were calculated using the EPA OCA 

Look Up Tables.  Although numerous controls are in place to prevent chemical releases and 

manage such consequences should an incident occur, no credit for active mitigation measures 

was taken into account in evaluating these scenarios.





Alternative Release Scenarios



Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS) assess the potential hazards that are more realistic than 

worst-case scenarios and are designed to assist in the development of emergency response 

plans.  EPA's RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines were used in modeling the 

alternative release scenarios.  A summary of the alternative release scenarios for Union Carbide 

Marine Terminal is provided in Table 3.  As required, alternative release scenarios are created for 

both a toxics and flammables.  These scenarios were calculated using the EPA OCA Look Up 

Tables.  Although numerous controls are in place to prevent chemical releases and manage such 

consequences should an incident occur, no credit for active mitigation measures was taken into 

account in evaluating these scenarios.

Five-Year A

ccident History

Union Carbide Marine Terminal, in the past five (5) years, has not incurred any chemical releases 

that resulted in any known onsite or offsite deaths, injuries, significant damage, evacuations or 

sheltering in place.  



Accidental Release Prevention Policies



Union Carbide Marine Terminal is committed to operate and maintain its facility in a safe and 

environmentally friendly manner.  Union Carbide Marine Terminal incorporates Dow Chemical's 

Global Management Systems and Emergency Response Plan with the rules and regulations set 

forth by the U.S. EPA Risk Management Plan and OSHA's Process Safety Management Program 

to ensure the safety of employees and public surroundings.

Union Carbide Marine Terminal designed its accident prevention program to comply with both the 

EPA RMP rule and with OSHA's Process Safety Management.  Union Carbide incorporates the 

Dow Chemical Operating Discipline Management Systems (ODMS), which globalize all Dow 

facilities with the same environmental, health, and safety regulations.  Included in Dow's ODMS 

are elements addressing the following:



-    Equipment Design - Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process 

    equipment are designed according to recognized industry standards and/or governmental 

    requirements.

-    Process Safety Information - Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment 

    information is documented, maintained up-to-date, and available to operating personnel.

-    Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) - PHAs are conducted every three (3) years to identify 

    major process hazard scenarios and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to 

    prevent their occurrence.

-    Episodic Risk Management - Periodic reviews are conducted to identify hazards which 

    could have significant community impact and to recommend corrective action(s) needed 

    to prevent their occurrence.  These reviews utilize advanced quantitative risk assessment 

    techniques.

-    Operational Safety Standar

ds - Design requirements for active and passive mitigation 

    controls used to prevent major process hazards are documented in operational safety 

    standards.

-    Operating Procedures - Operating procedures provide detail on how to safely operate a 

    process and are maintained up-to-date.

-    Operator Training/Certification Program - The plant has a training and testing program 

    which provides operators with the proper skills and knowledge prior to allowing them to 

    independently operate a process.

-    Technical Staff Training and Support - Trained technical staff employees are available 24 

    hours a day to support operations.

-    Maintenance Procedures - The plant has specific procedures for maintaining process 

    equipment so that it operates safely.

-    Maintenance Training -  The plant trains persons who perform routine or complex 

    maintenance tasks on process equipment.

-    Mechanical Integrity Program - Vessels (including shipping containers) and other 

    process equipment are periodically tested and/or inspected to ensure safe operation of 

    process equipment, following recognized industry standards and/or governmental 

    requirements.

-    Management of Change (MOC) - The plant has a management system to ensure that 

    modified facilities and processes will be safe to operate.

-    Pre-startup Safety Review - Reviews are conducted just prior to startup to ensure that 

    modified facilities and processes are safe for operation.

-    Incident Investigation - The plant has a program to ensure that accidents and incidents 

    are properly investigated to determine the cause(s) and to implement corrective action(s) 

    that are needed to prevent the event from reoccurring.

-    Employee Participation - The plant has a program to involve employees in prevention 

    program elements.

-    Hot Work Permit - The plant has a procedure to ensure that welding, cutting, and brazing 

    are safely performed in areas where flammables or combustible material may be present.

-    Contra

ctor Safety Program - The plant has a procedure to ensure that contractors are 

    properly trained and perform their work in compliance with safety requirements.

-    Compliance Audits - Periodic corporate and plant-led audits are conducted to ensure that 

    process operations comply with governmental and corporate requirements.

-    Operational Safety Program - Union Carbide has a comprehrensive program to ensure 

    that all the elements listed are implemented at every Union Carbide location.  This 

    program includes accountabilities for timely and proper implementation of the program 

    elements.



These general prevention elements are parts of an overall management system to prevent 

accidental chemical releases.  Union Carbide and its employees are committed to the standards 

that these management systems set, and have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure 

that they are meeting their own high standards for accident prevention.



Emergency Response Program



Union Carbide Marine Terminal maintains a written emergency response program to protect 

worker and public safety, as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for 

responding to releases of hazardous substances, including fire or explosion and is updated when 

necessary based on modifications made to the facility. 

The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including:



- Proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures.

- Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation.

- Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.

- Post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.

- Inspecting, testing, maintaining, and using emergency response equipment.



Union Carbide Marine Terminal maintains a trained emergency squad to handle fire, explosions, 

toxic vapor releases, spills, and medical emergencies.  The facility trains and drills with local 

emergency responders to enhance their skills a

nd tactics for responding to an accidental 

chemical release.  Critiques are held on drills and actual events.  

The emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively 

protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Detailed 

emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the Texas City/La Marque Local 

Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Union Carbide Marine Terminal continually strives to improve its safety-related systems.  Dow 

Chemical's Management Systems (ODMS) has globalized its policies and procedures to provide 

each facility with the most-improved and efficient means to minimize environmental impacts on-

site and to the public.  Union Carbide Marine Terminal also continues to improve by implementing 

an incident investigation database known as GIRD (Global Incident Reporting Database) to 

monitor potential risks of future incidents.  These improvements, along with monthly reviews of 

current safety protocols, reduce the risk of future incidents.
